title: How Mercedes Went From Hell to Heaven
subtitle: Value-over-volume, platform efficiency & capital discipline
tldr: Shift from volume to premium mix & pricing discipline.
Capital allocation guided by ROIC logic.
markdown:
## TL;DR
- Mercedes moved from **volume mindset** to **value-over-volume** (premium mix, pricing discipline).
- Reduced product complexity with **platform + modular efficiency**.
- Introduced **capital discipline**: fewer low-return initiatives, more ROIC-driven bets.

## Context
Over time, chasing share and volume can dilute a premium brand and compress margins.

## The strategic shift
### 1) Product & mix
- Focus on higher-margin segments
- Cleaner portfolio, fewer variants

### 2) Pricing discipline
- Fewer aggressive promotions
- Brand-led pricing and channel control

### 3) Operating model
- Standardization where it reduces cost
- Faster cycles, lower unit cost

### 4) Capital discipline
- Clear business cases
- Cut low-return initiatives

## Risks & trade-offs
- Premium focus can reduce volume — you must tolerate it.
- Standardization can hurt differentiation if design/experience is weak.

## What I would do next
Build a dashboard: **mix %, ASP, discount rate, segment contribution margin**, plus a **complexity tax** metric.

title: Zalando: Unit Economics Under Pressure
subtitle: Returns, logistics costs & the margin reality of e-commerce
tldr: Returns behave like a hidden COGS in fashion e-commerce.
Logistics + last-mile quality is a strategic lever, not a support function.
Contribution margin clarity beats top-line growth vanity.
markdown:
## TL;DR
- In fashion e-commerce, **returns = hidden COGS**.
- Logistics performance is a **strategic lever**.
- Use contribution margin per cohort, not just revenue growth.

## Core drivers
- Return rate by category
- Picking/packing cost per order
- Last-mile cost & service levels
- Discount rate and promo dependency

## What I would do next
Segment customers by return behavior, enforce smarter incentives, and track contribution margin by cohort.

title: N26: Growth vs Risk — When Compliance Becomes Strategy
subtitle: Fintech scaling, controls, and the cost of weak risk foundations
tldr: Risk/compliance maturity is a scaling constraint, not a back-office issue.
Growth without controls creates regulatory drag and reputation cost.
Operating model must be designed for auditability.
markdown:
## TL;DR
- Compliance is not bureaucracy — it is **scaling infrastructure**.
- Weak controls turn into regulatory drag, operational cost, and reputation risk.

## What changes when you scale
- More markets = more KYC/AML complexity
- Higher transaction volumes = more monitoring requirements

## What I would do next
Define a risk operating model with clear ownership, metrics, and audit-ready processes.

title: Adidas: Rebuilding Brand Heat Without Burning Margin
subtitle: Product cadence, channel strategy & pricing power
tldr: Brand heat must translate into pricing power — otherwise it’s just noise.
Channel mix (DTC vs wholesale) changes economics and control.
Inventory discipline is a strategic moat in consumer goods.
markdown:
## TL;DR
- Brand momentum matters only if it becomes **pricing power**.
- Channel mix drives margin, data, and customer control.

## Strategic levers
- Product cadence (drops vs always-on)
- Channel strategy (DTC vs wholesale)
- Inventory discipline

## What I would do next
Track discount rate as a KPI, segment products by pricing power, and align inventory to demand signals.

title: Tesla: The Operating System Behind the Cost Advantage
subtitle: Manufacturing simplification, vertical integration & speed loops
tldr: Cost advantage is built via process design, not slogans.
Speed loops shorten learning cycles and reduce rework cost.
Vertical integration is a trade-off: control vs complexity.
markdown:
## TL;DR
- Operating model creates cost advantage.
- Faster iteration reduces rework and improves quality.

## Trade-offs
- Integration increases control but adds complexity.
- Standardization lowers cost but risks sameness.

## What I would do next
Quantify savings per design simplification and link it to cycle-time KPIs.

title: Controlling in Germany: The Hidden Career Accelerator
subtitle: Budgeting, variance analysis & performance steering in practice
tldr: Controlling is business partnering + performance steering.
You own planning, variance analysis, and KPI reviews.
markdown:
## TL;DR
- In German companies, controlling is the function that *steers performance*.

## Typical responsibilities
- Budgeting and forecasting
- Actual vs plan commentary
- KPI dashboards

## What I would do next
Build a monthly performance deck: KPIs → drivers → actions → risks → outlook.
